title: The citizens of Greece said no - good news for tourism?
text:
The citizens of Greece said no - good news for tourism? Adv: 
Jul 05, 2015 Adv: 
A French tourist in Athens, a French retired teacher, says. "It brings me sorrow. Europe without Greece would be sad. They shouldn't leave a European country like Greece flat broke." 
The citizens of Greece said no to a European bailout for this bankrupt country. Credibility and trust between Europe and Greece has been seriously damaged. Over the next few hours, both sides' willingness to re-start negotiations and under what conditions remains the most important next step. 
Greece based news outlets including Ta Nea and Ethnos, said that Greece would be prepared to raise the VAT on hotel stays -- a key rate for tourism -- from 6.5 percent to 13 percent, while a demand raising the VAT on restaurants from 13 percent to 23 percent has not been resolved. 
An exit of Greece out of the EURO would take the European Union into unchartered territory, and for tourism it may be good news, Greece would by far become even more attractive, even with higher taxes. 
Greece would remain a bargain and an attractive tourism destination. 
Paul Krugman, another Nobel winner, who writes for The New York Times, agrees. A 'No' result may force Greece to exit the euro, "which would be hugely disruptive in the short run. But it will also offer Greece itself a chance for real recovery." 
Decisions have to be taken soon on whether to return to the path of negotiations or consider the alternative of a Eurozone exit, a Deutsche Bank specialist writes. 
The ouzo flows tonight when those wanting the NO vote are celebrating everywhere in Greece.
